title: Complex Sentences & Clauses
description: Master dependent and independent clauses, subordinating conjunctions, and sentence variety for more sophisticated writing
description_zh: 掌握从属和独立从句、从属连词以及句式变化，提升写作水平
objectives: Identify independent and dependent clauses
Use subordinating conjunctions correctly (although, because, while, unless)
Combine simple sentences into complex sentences
Avoid sentence fragments and run-ons with complex structures
objectives_zh: 识别独立从句和从属从句
正确使用从属连词（although, because, while, unless）
将简单句组合成复杂句
避免复杂结构中的句子片段和连写句

sections.title: Independent vs. Dependent Clauses
sections.content:
An independent clause can stand alone as a complete sentence. It has a subject and verb: The MRT train arrived.

A dependent clause cannot stand alone. It begins with a subordinating conjunction: Although the MRT train arrived (incomplete - what happened?).

When combined: Although the MRT train arrived, we missed it because we were late.

sections.title: Subordinating Conjunctions
sections.content:
Common subordinating conjunctions: although, because, since, while, when, if, unless, until, after, before.

They show relationships:
- Cause/Effect: because, since
- Contrast: although, while
- Condition: if, unless
- Time: when, after, before, until

Example: Unless it rains, the NEA will lift the haze advisory.

sections.title: Creating Sentence Variety
sections.content:
Vary your sentence structure:
1. Start with dependent clause: While studying at the National Library, I discovered a new interest.
2. Start with independent clause: I discovered a new interest while studying at the National Library.
3. Use multiple dependent clauses: When the exam ended, I felt relieved because I had prepared well.

Good writers mix simple, compound, and complex sentences.

title: Active & Passive Voice

在适当时使用主动语态加强写作

sections.title: Active vs. Passive Voice
sections.content:
Active voice: Subject performs the action.
The teacher marked the exam papers.

Passive voice: Subject receives the action.
The exam papers were marked by the teacher.

Passive voice structure: [Object] + be verb + past participle + (by + agent)
The agent (by the teacher) can be omitted if unknown or unimportant.

sections.title: When to Use Passive Voice
sections.content:
Use passive voice when:
1. The action is more important than who did it: The Singapore Flyer was built in 2008.
2. The doer is unknown: My bicycle was stolen.
3. In scientific/formal writing: The solution was heated to 60 degrees C.
4. To be tactful: A mistake was made (instead of You made a mistake).

Avoid passive voice when it makes writing unclear or wordy.

sections.title: Transforming Between Voices
sections.content:
Active to Passive transformation:
1. Active: The NEA monitors air quality.
2. Identify object (air quality) and make it the subject
3. Add correct be verb + past participle
4. Passive: Air quality is monitored by the NEA.

Passive to Active:
1. Passive: The hawker center was renovated by HDB.
2. Make the agent (HDB) the subject
3. Active: HDB renovated the hawker center.

description: Develop skills in building logical arguments, using evidence effectively, and writing persuasive essays
description_zh: 培养构建逻辑论证、有效使用证据和撰写说服性文章的技能

objectives_zh: 用清晰的论点陈述组织说服性文章

sections.title: Persuasive Essay Structure
sections.content:
Persuasive essay structure:

1. Introduction:
   - Hook (question, statistic, anecdote)
   - Background context
   - Thesis statement (your position)

2. Body Paragraphs (2-3):
   - Topic sentence (one reason)
   - Evidence (facts, statistics, examples)
   - Explanation of how evidence supports thesis
   - Transition to next paragraph

3. Counterargument Paragraph:
   - Acknowledge opposing view
   - Refute with evidence

4. Conclusion:
   - Restate thesis
   - Summarize main points
   - Call to action or final thought

sections.title: Using Evidence Effectively
sections.content:
Strong evidence includes:
- Statistics: According to NEA, recycling rates in Singapore increased to 61% in 2022.
- Expert opinions: Dr. Lee from NUS states that...
- Real examples: When Tampines implemented the zero-waste initiative...
- Personal anecdotes (use sparingly): Last year at my school...

Always:
1. Introduce evidence with a signal phrase
2. Explain how it supports your point
3. Cite sources when using external information

sections.title: Persuasive Techniques
sections.content:
Three persuasive appeals:

1. Ethos (Credibility):
   - Show expertise or trustworthiness
   - As a student who uses public transport daily...

2. Pathos (Emotion):
   - Appeal to feelings
   - Imagine if every Singaporean household reduced plastic waste...

3. Logos (Logic):
   - Use facts and reasoning
   - If we increase bus frequency by 20%, waiting times will decrease proportionally.

Balance all three for effective persuasion.

sections.title: Sensory Details & Imagery
sections.content:
Descriptive writing appeals to the five senses:

- Sight: The durian's spiky green shell glistened under the market lights.
- Sound: Hawkers shouted their prices above the sizzling of woks.
- Smell: The aroma of freshly fried carrot cake filled the air.
- Taste: The kaya toast was sweet and creamy with a hint of pandan.
- Touch: The humid air clung to my skin as I walked through the MRT station.

Show, don't tell: Instead of It was hot, write Sweat trickled down my back as I waited for the bus.

sections.title: Figurative Language
sections.content:
Enhance descriptions with:

1. Simile (using like or as):
   The MRT platform was as crowded as a hawker center at lunchtime.

2. Metaphor (direct comparison):
   Orchard Road is a river of shoppers on weekends.

3. Personification (giving human qualities to objects):
   The afternoon sun beat down mercilessly on the concrete.

4. Hyperbole (exaggeration):
   I have told you a million times to bring your EZ-Link card!

Use figuratively language purposefully, not excessively.

sections.title: Expository Essay Structure
sections.content:
Expository writing explains or informs:

Types:
1. Process: How to apply for a student Concession Card
2. Cause-Effect: Why Singapore experiences haze from neighboring countries
3. Compare-Contrast: Public vs. Private schools in Singapore
4. Problem-Solution: Addressing food waste in school canteens

Structure:
- Introduction with clear thesis
- Body paragraphs with topic sentences
- Strong transitions (Furthermore, In addition, However, Consequently)
- Factual, objective tone
- Conclusion summarizing main points

title: Literary Devices & Analysis
description: Identify and analyze literary devices including symbolism, irony, foreshadowing, and theme in literature

sections.title: Symbolism
sections.content:
A symbol is something that represents something else beyond its literal meaning.

Common symbols:
- Weather: Storm = conflict, sunshine = hope
- Colors: Red = danger/passion, white = purity
- Objects: Keys = freedom, walls = barriers

Example: In a story about Singapore's independence, the national flag might symbolize unity and hope for the future.

To analyze symbolism:
1. Identify the symbol
2. Consider its literal meaning
3. Determine its deeper significance
4. Connect to the story's theme

sections.title: Types of Irony
sections.content:
Three types of irony:

1. Verbal Irony: Saying the opposite of what you mean
   - What lovely weather! (said during a thunderstorm)
   - Includes sarcasm

2. Situational Irony: Outcome opposite of what is expected
   - A fire station burns down
   - A student who never studies tops the class

3. Dramatic Irony: Audience knows something characters do not
   - In a story, readers know the helpful stranger is actually a thief, but the character trusts him

Irony often reveals theme or creates humor.

sections.title: Foreshadowing & Theme
sections.content:
Foreshadowing: Hints about future events
- Dark clouds gathering = trouble ahead
- A character's warning = danger coming
- Repeated images = significance later

Example: As he pocketed the extra change, he did not notice the security camera above. (foreshadows getting caught)

Theme: Central message or lesson
- Not the same as topic (topic = friendship, theme = True friends support each other in difficult times)
- Often universal and stated as a complete sentence
- Revealed through characters' actions, conflicts, and resolutions

Singapore literature often explores themes of multiculturalism, family expectations, and identity.

sections.title: Making Inferences
sections.content:
An inference is a logical conclusion based on evidence and reasoning.

Text: Sarah slammed her locker shut and stomped down the hallway, ignoring her friends' greetings.

Inference: Sarah is angry or upset about something.

To make good inferences:
1. Look for clues (actions, dialogue, descriptions)
2. Use prior knowledge
3. Ask What does this suggest?
4. Support inference with evidence from text

Avoid: Wild guesses without textual support

sections.title: Fact vs. Opinion
sections.content:
Fact: Can be verified or proven
- Singapore gained independence in 1965. (checkable)
- The Merlion is located at Marina Bay. (verifiable)

Opinion: Personal belief or judgment
- Singapore is the best country in Southeast Asia. (subjective)
- Chicken rice is delicious. (personal taste)

Watch for opinion markers:
- I think, I believe, in my opinion
- Should, ought to, must
- Adjectives (best, worst, beautiful, terrible)

Critical readers distinguish facts from opinions to evaluate arguments.

sections.title: Author's Purpose & Tone
sections.content:
Author's Purpose:
1. Inform: Provide facts (textbooks, news articles)
2. Persuade: Convince readers (editorials, advertisements)
3. Entertain: Amuse or engage (stories, poems)

Author's Tone (attitude toward subject):
- Formal vs. Informal
- Serious, humorous, sarcastic, sympathetic, critical

Clues to tone:
- Word choice (diction)
- Sentence structure
- Details included/excluded

Example: A news article about youth volunteerism using words like inspiring and commendable has an approving tone.

Bias: Unfair preference for or against something. Look for one-sided arguments and loaded language.
